speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: SCENE I. Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: A crowd of people; among them ARTEMIDORUS and the  Soothsayer. Flourish. Enter CAESAR, BRUTUS,  CASSIUS, CASCA, DECIUS BRUTUS, METELLUS CIMBER,  TREBONIUS, CINNA, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, POPILIUS, PUBLIUS, and others

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: [To the Soothsayer]  The ides of March are come.

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: Ay, Caesar; but not gone.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: Hail, Caesar! read this schedule.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Trebonius doth desire you to o'erread,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: At your best leisure, this his humble suit.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: O Caesar, read mine first; for mine's a suit

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: That touches Caesar nearer: read it, great Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: What touches us ourself shall be last served.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: Delay not, Caesar; read it instantly.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: What, is the fellow mad?

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: Sirrah, give place.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: What, urge you your petitions in the street?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Come to the Capitol.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: CAESAR goes up to the Senate-House, the rest following

speaker: POPILIUS
text_entry: I wish your enterprise to-day may thrive.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: What enterprise, Popilius?

speaker: POPILIUS
text_entry: Fare you well.

speaker: POPILIUS
text_entry: Advances to CAESAR

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What said Popilius Lena?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: He wish'd to-day our enterprise might thrive.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I fear our purpose is discovered.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Look, how he makes to Caesar; mark him.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Casca, be sudden, for we fear prevention.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Brutus, what shall be done? If this be known,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For I will slay myself.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Cassius, be constant:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Popilius Lena speaks not of our purposes;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For, look, he smiles, and Caesar doth not change.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Trebonius knows his time; for, look you, Brutus.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: He draws Mark Antony out of the way.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Exeunt ANTONY and TREBONIUS

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Where is Metellus Cimber? Let him go,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: And presently prefer his suit to Caesar.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He is address'd: press near and second him.

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: Casca, you are the first that rears your hand.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Are we all ready? What is now amiss

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: That Caesar and his senate must redress?

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Most high, most mighty, and most puissant Caesar,

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Metellus Cimber throws before thy seat

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: An humble heart,--

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Kneeling

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: I must prevent thee, Cimber.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: These couchings and these lowly courtesies

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Might fire the blood of ordinary men,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: And turn pre-ordinance and first decree

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Into the law of children. Be not fond,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: To think that Caesar bears such rebel blood

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: That will be thaw'd from the true quality

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: With that which melteth fools; I mean, sweet words,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Low-crooked court'sies and base spaniel-fawning.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Thy brother by decree is banished:

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: If thou dost bend and pray and fawn for him,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: I spurn thee like a cur out of my way.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Know, Caesar doth not wrong, nor without cause

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Will he be satisfied.

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Is there no voice more worthy than my own

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: To sound more sweetly in great Caesar's ear

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: For the repealing of my banish'd brother?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I kiss thy hand, but not in flattery, Caesar;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Desiring thee that Publius Cimber may

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Have an immediate freedom of repeal.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: What, Brutus!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Pardon, Caesar; Caesar, pardon:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: As low as to thy foot doth Cassius fall,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To beg enfranchisement for Publius Cimber.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I could be well moved, if I were as you:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If I could pray to move, prayers would move me:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But I am constant as the northern star,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Of whose true-fix'd and resting quality

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: There is no fellow in the firmament.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The skies are painted with unnumber'd sparks,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: They are all fire and every one doth shine,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But there's but one in all doth hold his place:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: So in the world; 'tis furnish'd well with men,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And men are flesh and blood, and apprehensive;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Yet in the number I do know but one

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That unassailable holds on his rank,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Unshaked of motion: and that I am he,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Let me a little show it, even in this;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That I was constant Cimber should be banish'd,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And constant do remain to keep him so.

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: O Caesar,--

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Hence! wilt thou lift up Olympus?

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Great Caesar,--

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Doth not Brutus bootless kneel?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Speak, hands for me!

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: CASCA first, then the other Conspirators and BRUTUS stab CAESAR

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Et tu, Brute! Then fall, Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Dies

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: Liberty! Freedom! Tyranny is dead!

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: Run hence, proclaim, cry it about the streets.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Some to the common pulpits, and cry out

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: 'Liberty, freedom, and enfranchisement!'

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: People and senators, be not affrighted;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Fly not; stand stiff: ambition's debt is paid.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Go to the pulpit, Brutus.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: And Cassius too.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Where's Publius?

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: Here, quite confounded with this mutiny.

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Stand fast together, lest some friend of Caesar's

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Should chance--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Talk not of standing. Publius, good cheer;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: There is no harm intended to your person,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Nor to no Roman else: so tell them, Publius.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And leave us, Publius; lest that the people,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Rushing on us, should do your age some mischief.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Do so: and let no man abide this deed,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But we the doers.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter TREBONIUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Where is Antony?

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: Fled to his house amazed:

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: Men, wives and children stare, cry out and run

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: As it were doomsday.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Fates, we will know your pleasures:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That we shall die, we know; 'tis but the time

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And drawing days out, that men stand upon.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Why, he that cuts off twenty years of life

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Cuts off so many years of fearing death.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Grant that, and then is death a benefit:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: So are we Caesar's friends, that have abridged

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: His time of fearing death. Stoop, Romans, stoop,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And let us bathe our hands in Caesar's blood

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Up to the elbows, and besmear our swords:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Then walk we forth, even to the market-place,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And, waving our red weapons o'er our heads,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let's all cry 'Peace, freedom and liberty!'

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Stoop, then, and wash. How many ages hence

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Shall this our lofty scene be acted over

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In states unborn and accents yet unknown!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: How many times shall Caesar bleed in sport,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That now on Pompey's basis lies along

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No worthier than the dust!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: So oft as that shall be,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: So often shall the knot of us be call'd

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The men that gave their country liberty.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: What, shall we forth?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Ay, every man away:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Brutus shall lead; and we will grace his heels

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Soft! who comes here? A friend of Antony's.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Thus, Brutus, did my master bid me kneel:

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Thus did Mark Antony bid me fall down;

speaker: Servant
text_entry: And, being prostrate, thus he bade me say:

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Brutus is noble, wise, valiant, and honest;

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Caesar was mighty, bold, royal, and loving:

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Say I love Brutus, and I honour him;

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Say I fear'd Caesar, honour'd him and loved him.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: If Brutus will vouchsafe that Antony

speaker: Servant
text_entry: May safely come to him, and be resolved

speaker: Servant
text_entry: How Caesar hath deserved to lie in death,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Mark Antony shall not love Caesar dead

speaker: Servant
text_entry: So well as Brutus living; but will follow

speaker: Servant
text_entry: The fortunes and affairs of noble Brutus

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Thorough the hazards of this untrod state

speaker: Servant
text_entry: With all true faith. So says my master Antony.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Thy master is a wise and valiant Roman;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I never thought him worse.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Tell him, so please him come unto this place,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He shall be satisfied; and, by my honour,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Depart untouch'd.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: I'll fetch him presently.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I know that we shall have him well to friend.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I wish we may: but yet have I a mind

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That fears him much; and my misgiving still

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Falls shrewdly to the purpose.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But here comes Antony.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter ANTONY

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Welcome, Mark Antony.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: O mighty Caesar! dost thou lie so low?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Are all thy conquests, glories, triumphs, spoils,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Shrunk to this little measure? Fare thee well.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I know not, gentlemen, what you intend,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Who else must be let blood, who else is rank:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: If I myself, there is no hour so fit

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: As Caesar's death hour, nor no instrument

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Of half that worth as those your swords, made rich

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: With the most noble blood of all this world.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I do beseech ye, if you bear me hard,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Now, whilst your purpled hands do reek and smoke,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Fulfil your pleasure. Live a thousand years,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I shall not find myself so apt to die:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: No place will please me so, no mean of death,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: As here by Caesar, and by you cut off,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The choice and master spirits of this age.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O Antony, beg not your death of us.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Though now we must appear bloody and cruel,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: As, by our hands and this our present act,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You see we do, yet see you but our hands

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And this the bleeding business they have done:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Our hearts you see not; they are pitiful;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And pity to the general wrong of Rome--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: As fire drives out fire, so pity pity--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Hath done this deed on Caesar. For your part,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To you our swords have leaden points, Mark Antony:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Our arms, in strength of malice, and our hearts

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Of brothers' temper, do receive you in

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: With all kind love, good thoughts, and reverence.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Your voice shall be as strong as any man's

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In the disposing of new dignities.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Only be patient till we have appeased

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The multitude, beside themselves with fear,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And then we will deliver you the cause,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why I, that did love Caesar when I struck him,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Have thus proceeded.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I doubt not of your wisdom.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Let each man render me his bloody hand:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: First, Marcus Brutus, will I shake with you;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Next, Caius Cassius, do I take your hand;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Now, Decius Brutus, yours: now yours, Metellus;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Yours, Cinna; and, my valiant Casca, yours;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Though last, not last in love, yours, good Trebonius.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Gentlemen all,--alas, what shall I say?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: My credit now stands on such slippery ground,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That one of two bad ways you must conceit me,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Either a coward or a flatterer.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That I did love thee, Caesar, O, 'tis true:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: If then thy spirit look upon us now,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Shall it not grieve thee dearer than thy death,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To see thy thy Anthony making his peace,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Shaking the bloody fingers of thy foes,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Most noble! in the presence of thy corse?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Weeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: It would become me better than to close

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: In terms of friendship with thine enemies.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bay'd, brave hart;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Here didst thou fall; and here thy hunters stand,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Sign'd in thy spoil, and crimson'd in thy lethe.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: O world, thou wast the forest to this hart;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And this, indeed, O world, the heart of thee.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: How like a deer, strucken by many princes,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Dost thou here lie!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Mark Antony,--

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Pardon me, Caius Cassius:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The enemies of Caesar shall say this;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Then, in a friend, it is cold modesty.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I blame you not for praising Caesar so;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But what compact mean you to have with us?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Will you be prick'd in number of our friends;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Or shall we on, and not depend on you?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Therefore I took your hands, but was, indeed,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Sway'd from the point, by looking down on Caesar.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Friends am I with you all and love you all,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Upon this hope, that you shall give me reasons

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Or else were this a savage spectacle:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Our reasons are so full of good regard

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That were you, Antony, the son of Caesar,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You should be satisfied.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That's all I seek:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And am moreover suitor that I may

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Produce his body to the market-place;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And in the pulpit, as becomes a friend,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Speak in the order of his funeral.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You shall, Mark Antony.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Brutus, a word with you.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Aside to BRUTUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You know not what you do: do not consent

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That Antony speak in his funeral:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Know you how much the people may be moved

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: By that which he will utter?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By your pardon;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I will myself into the pulpit first,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And show the reason of our Caesar's death:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What Antony shall speak, I will protest

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He speaks by leave and by permission,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And that we are contented Caesar shall

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Have all true rites and lawful ceremonies.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It shall advantage more than do us wrong.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I know not what may fall; I like it not.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Mark Antony, here, take you Caesar's body.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You shall not in your funeral speech blame us,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But speak all good you can devise of Caesar,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And say you do't by our permission;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Else shall you not have any hand at all

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: About his funeral: and you shall speak

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: In the same pulpit whereto I am going,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: After my speech is ended.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Be it so.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I do desire no more.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Prepare the body then, and follow us.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt all but ANTONY

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: O, pardon me, thou bleeding piece of earth,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That I am meek and gentle with these butchers!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Thou art the ruins of the noblest man

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That ever lived in the tide of times.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Over thy wounds now do I prophesy,--

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Which, like dumb mouths, do ope their ruby lips,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To beg the voice and utterance of my tongue--

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: A curse shall light upon the limbs of men;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Domestic fury and fierce civil strife

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Shall cumber all the parts of Italy;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Blood and destruction shall be so in use

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And dreadful objects so familiar

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That mothers shall but smile when they behold

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Their infants quarter'd with the hands of war;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: All pity choked with custom of fell deeds:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And Caesar's spirit, ranging for revenge,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: With Ate by his side come hot from hell,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Shall in these confines with a monarch's voice

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Cry  'Havoc,' and let slip the dogs of war;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That this foul deed shall smell above the earth

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: With carrion men, groaning for burial.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You serve Octavius Caesar, do you not?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: I do, Mark Antony.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Caesar did write for him to come to Rome.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: He did receive his letters, and is coming;

speaker: Servant
text_entry: And bid me say to you by word of mouth--

speaker: Servant
text_entry: O Caesar!--

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Seeing the body

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Thy heart is big, get thee apart and weep.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Passion, I see, is catching; for mine eyes,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Began to water. Is thy master coming?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: He lies to-night within seven leagues of Rome.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Post back with speed, and tell him what hath chanced:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: No Rome of safety for Octavius yet;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Hie hence, and tell him so. Yet, stay awhile;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corse

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Into the market-place: there shall I try

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: In my oration, how the people take

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The cruel issue of these bloody men;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: According to the which, thou shalt discourse

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To young Octavius of the state of things.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Lend me your hand.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt with CAESAR's body
